metadata.case_name: Appellant v. Dr. D. P. Meshram

facts.text: Appellant and respondents 1 to 4 were candidates nominated for election to Maharashtra Legislative Assembly from constituency No. 190 Nagpur III, reserved for Scheduled Castes.
Poll taken on February 27, 1962; respondent No. 1 Dr. D. P. Meshram polled highest votes and was declared elected.

Appellant filed election petition alleging (a) respondent No. 1 embraced Buddhism on March 17, 1957, ceased to be Scheduled Caste per Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950, disentitled for reserved seat; (b) guilty of corrupt practices.
Tribunal held corrupt practices not established but respondent No. 1 embraced Buddhism, ineligible; set aside election. Prayer to declare appellant elected not granted as multiple candidates.

Respondent No. 1 appealed to Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench (Appeal No. 115 of 1962); High Court reversed Tribunal on conversion, held fact not established, upheld election. Judgment dated February 7, 8, 1963.

Mass conversion to Buddhism by Dr. Ambedkar at Nagpur on October 14, 1956; about 5 lakhs Scheduled Castes persons attended; Dr. Ambedkar and wife recited three refuges, five precepts, 22 vows; mass ordination followed. Respondent No. 1 admitted event, was party member but did not attend due to water supply arrangements.

Mass conversion continued after October 14, 1956. Meeting at Lashkari Bagh, Nagpur, two or three days after Holi 1957 (around March 17, 1957), presided by P.W. 9 Ramrattan; respondent No. 1 and others including P.W. 2, 5, 10 converted.
P.W. 9 Ramrattan, P.W. 2 Akant Mate, P.W. 5 Devaji Bhagat, P.W. 10 Wasudeo Dongre testified to respondent No. 1's conversion at March 1957 meeting.
Rift in Republican Party of India after Dr. Ambedkar's death; appellant and witnesses in Haridas Awade group, respondent No. 1 in Khobargade group.

Declaration Ex. 42 dated July 5, 1957 signed by respondent No. 1 and others: 'We... do hereby affirm that we embraced Buddha religion on 17-3-1957 and no longer since remain Harijans.' Filed in High Court writ petition re Nagpur Corporation selection.
Respondent No. 1 admitted signing Ex. 42 but claimed political pressure/duped by Akant Mate; explanation varied from written statement.

Wedding invitation for respondent No. 1's daughters Lalita and Pushpa Lata bore picture of Lord Buddha and inscription 'Obeisances to Buddha'; respondent No. 1 one of hosts. Bridegrooms insisted on Buddhist ritual.

Shiva temple near appellant's house in Gautamnagar converted to Buddha temple on June 6, 1959; presided by respondent No. 1; idol of Buddha installed over buried Shiva Linga/Pind. Witnesses P.W. 11 Budhaji Godbole, P.W. 14 Kisan Shende, appellant.
Respondent No. 1 admitted facts but claimed no Shiva temple constructed on exchanged plot; committee decided Shiva temple in 1959-60 but built Buddha temple.
No register of converts mandatorily signed; respondent No. 1's name absent not conclusive.

legal_issues.text: Whether respondent No. 1 Dr. D. P. Meshram was entitled to be a candidate for election to reserved Scheduled Caste constituency, having allegedly embraced Buddhism and ceased to be member of Scheduled Caste per Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondent No. 1 embraced Buddhism on March 17, 1957 at mass conversion meeting post-Holi, testified by P.W. 9,2,5,10; ceased to be Scheduled Caste.
Corroborated by Ex. 42 declaration dated July 5, 1957 admitting conversion; wedding invitation with Buddha picture; conversion of Shiva temple to Buddha temple.

respondent_arguments.text: No conversion to Buddhism; witnesses biased due to Republican Party rift.

Signed Ex. 42 under political pressure/duped; wedding invitation treated Buddha as 11th incarnation; no Shiva temple on plot, idle land used for Buddha idol; name absent from converts register; only Bhikku can convert.

court_reasoning.text: Witnesses' evidence consistent, ring of truth; Tribunal believed them; bias noted but good grounds to accept given mass conversion context Oct 1956, respondent's prominence and party affiliation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Probability respondent followed Dr. Ambedkar in embracing Buddhism.

court_reasoning.text: Rejected respondent's Ex. 42 explanation as varying; declaration corroborates conversion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Once explanation rejected, declaration shows ceased to be Hindu.

court_reasoning.text: Wedding invitation with Buddha picture inconsistent with remaining Hindu; unlikely to marry daughters to Buddhists if Hindu.
Shiva temple converted to Buddha Vihar June 6, 1959; Shiva Linga buried, Buddha idol installed atop; respondent presided; strongest corroboration as Hindu would not desecrate Shiva Linga.
No mandatory register; absence not negative. Any Buddhist can convert others per Dr. Ambedkar; no Bhikku required; vows/precepts suffice as in 1956 ceremony.
'Professes' in cl.3 SC Order means open declaration of belief; public declaration/conduct shows ceased professing Hindu. Hindu in Order narrow sense excluding Buddhists/Sikhs.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Art.25 Expl.II expands Hindu only for that purpose; no need mention Sikhs if inclusive.

holdings.text: Respondent No. 1 ceased to be Hindu by embracing Buddhism, ineligible for Scheduled Caste reserved seat per cl.3 Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950.

precedents_cited.relevance: High Court followed its meaning of 'professes a religion'; Supreme Court distinguished/applied differently emphasizing open declaration.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: No person professing religion different from Hindu or Sikh deemed Scheduled Caste member; respondent ceased professing Hindu.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Expands 'Hindu' to include Buddhists etc. only for sub-cl.(b) cl.2 Art.25 social reform; not for SC Order.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside; Tribunal's order restored setting aside respondent No. 1's election on ground of ineligibility due to conversion to Buddhism.
outcome.relief_granted: Election of respondent No. 1 set aside
outcome.costs: Costs throughout borne by respondent No. 1

key_quotes.text: "We, the following signatories, do hereby affirm that we embraced Buddha religion on 17-3-1957 and no longer since remain Harijans." (Ex. 42)
key_quotes.speaker: respondent

key_quotes.text: Notwithstanding anything contained in paragraph 2, no person who professes a religion different from the Hindu or the Sikh religion shall be deemed to be a member of a Scheduled Caste.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: For however great the admiration or regard a Hindu may have for Lord Buddha, he would shudder at the idea of desecrating a Shiva Linga in this manner.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Strongest corroboration of conversion via temple conversion.
